> I don't see the point keeping that project going and am happy to point to this package and/or give up the "faker" PyPi namespace... let me know what I can do to help

You can add 'joke2k' as owner to the package, and 'curella.org' (that's my username for historical reasons) as 'maintainer'.

As for the future of `fake-factory`, I need to check exactly how removing a package works.

If the name gets released, I don't want anyone to squat the name and potentially distribute malicious code under that name. In that case, I think we can upload a new version that simply raises an helpful error. We may have a 'grace period' (i'm thinking 6 months) during which we upload to both and issue a warning instead of raising the error.

Any thoughts on how to handle the transition?
 thanks @deepthawtz .

I think this is a good start, but we will also need some period of time during which both names have the same package, with the warning only on the `fake-factory` side. Maybe that can start 3 months from now (ie: June 15th)?
 No, I think what you've done is perfect so far.

What I'm proposing is that in 3 month we will upload the code in this repo to _both_ `fake-factory` and `factory`, with just two small differences:
1. The `faker` package will not have any warning
2. The `fake-factory` package will have a warning

Then, on Sept. 15h, we will pull the plug on `fake-factory`. We either replace it with an 'empty' package (ie: it will contain _just_ the warning) or we remove the package completely from PyPI.

Basically the timeline is still 6 months, but within it we have 3 months of 'overlap' to help transition.

 @deepthawtz yes, you're correct. According to my proposal, that date should say June 15th.

You can keep the message as it is, and we can move the timeline by 3 months. Basically:
- Sept. 15th: Start transition period. This repo gets uploaded to both, warning only on `fake-factory`
- Dec. 15th: End transition period. `fake-factory` gets replaced by a 'shell' package.

  The final goal is put to a good use the time spent by who created a provider for this project.

Non-exhaustive list of possible options (not necessarily mutually exclusive):
- Page in the docs listing packages (easy-peasy #320 )
- Packages will contain a `faker-provider` in their `setup.py`'s `keywords` attribute, so they can easily found on PyPI. The docs will point to the search results page
- Bonus points with :sparkles: : cli option that parses a page or queries PyPI for providers to download and install.

Options I'd rather avoid:
- `faker` umbrella github org, and have everyone bring their code on GitHub (which not everybody may be OK with) and under the org. Also brings issues of governance.
- just accepting every single provider that gets proposed. We simply don't have the necessary time and resources to guarantee speedy reviews and quality control.
 @danhuss I'm thinking the upload on PyPI should be optional. On the page we'd list URL (could be a repo, could be your package's page on GH). On the same page, we can also have a link to the PyPI search results. If you decide not to publish your package on PyPI, your provider will simply be listed only once.

  We can't possibly cover 100% of the cases. We will end up with instances of providers that are very similar to each other except for that one difference that matters to that one person.

Currently, you can create a custom provider (http://fake-factory.readthedocs.org/en/stable/index.html#how-to-create-a-provider). You could include it in your project or, if you want to reuse it across projects, make it its own python package and link to it.

That said, I'm interested in finding a longer term solution to this issue.

I'm willing to maintain a list of community-supported providers in the docs, but I'm -0 on putting them under a `faker` umbrella org, because that puts the burdain of those packages (taking care of code, community, governance, etc) to the maintainers of `faker` (ie: me and @joke2k).

Would be really cool if faker had its own 'packages store' where you can discover and download providers from, but that involves server expenses we don't have the resources for.

  `faker.Faker` is not a class, but a class method. `faker.Faker` is just another name for `faker.factory.Factory.create` (I agree this is confusing and a little mind-bending).

I think the solution to your issue is to subclass from `faker.Factory`:

``` python
from faker import Factory

class Faker2(Factory):
    pass
```

  Not every combination of digits that makes up zipcode results in a valid zipcode. Zipcodes are pretty much arbitrary numbers associate with geographical boundaries (or, in some cases, companies). 

The only way to just have valid zipcodes would be to choose at random from a list of known valid zipcodes, instead of generating them from an algorithm.

I'm afraid that including such a list of valid zipcodes for each provider may result in a maintenance burden. Zipcodes are constantly added and removed in various country, and we can't possibly keep up with that.

That's one of the reason why my latest efforts are focused on #90 and #178 . With those in place, you could use your own custom provider tailored to your specific needs.

Assuming this PR is merged in, providers will have two options: using the list or using the dict. I don't really see any advantages on using `expand_to_list` rather than just declaring the list.

Re: the user case of 'merging choices' something like `formats = formats_male + formats_female` would become either:

``` python
formats = {}
formats = update(formats_female)
formats = update(formats_male)
```

or, if the two sets have keys in common, and we want their probability to be the sum instead of being overridden:

``` python
from collections import Counter

formats = Counter(formats_female) + Counter(formats_male)
```

Of course, we could provide some light utility functions for those cases.
 re: sorting: I don't think sorting is relevant.

re: seed: the seed is set globally on the `random` module, just as the `state` of the generator. Sadly there is no way to get the 'current seed', reason why I had to go with setting the state in my test.

  The core of the issue is deciding if providing an implementation for wighted `random.choice` is out of scope for this project or not.

If we decide we want to go down that route, we need to modify `BaseProvider.random_element` and all other provider methods that use it to accept an optional parameter containing the probabilities.

Once we have that, we need to decide if we want to ship our own implementation, or we want to reuse NumPy (http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.random.choice.html#numpy.random.choice)
 (which will make NumPy an optional dependency for people who wants to use the feature)

An alternative approach would be to let people specify what 'choice function' they want (defaulting to `random.choice`) and let them pass custom arguments to it. We'll still have to update all the providers, but I think this is approach is more flexible for users

So currently, if you do

``` python
f1 = Faker()
f2 = Faker()
f1.seed(123)
```

the `f2` object will effectively be seeded with `123` too due to all of the generators sharing the same `faker.generator.random` `Random()` instance, which is not really optimal.

I would be happy to do the work to fix this (by making the `random` object actually per-`Generator`), if you guys think it's a good idea.

  Desc: Updated first names to be reflect the most common US adult names for people 15-55 years old based on census birth records and to be used proportionally to their realistic frequency.  Last names updated to be the top 1000 US surnames weighted by frequency.

This is my first pull request and I'm not sure how to leave out the .gitignore.  I work on a mac and had to add .DS_Store.

Hey, first thanks all of you for all the awesome work on this module.  It's been a huge help to me over the years.

One of the things that's bugged me was that US names ended up being exceptional too frequently.  There are quite a lot of names and they're all used perfectly randomly.  I'm modeling sample documents for OCR purposes (checks mostly) and the high concentration of european names was a bit unrealistic.  
I wanted to make it use common names based on how common they are with a weighted dict - then to dig into it and you already HAVE it designed in.  Just no data for it.

So I took US baby names from census data from the 60s, 70s, 80s and 90s and the numbers that came with them to build weighted dicts for EN_US.  Something similar for last name, but just from current data.

https://www.ssa.gov/OACT/babynames/decades/names1960s.html
http://names.mongabay.com/data/1000.html

This fits my needs much better.  It might be of use to others.  **It might be more appropriate to build it in as a separate region (EN_USw) or something to leave the existing data.**  I'm not quite sure how to do that though.  I'd welcome suggestions if you think it'd be useful, but as an addition, not an update.

Looking through some of the open issues, I'd still like to further refine this and other providers to have some agreement in the generated data.  Even what I've just produced is a little wonky in that it's mixing cultural first names and last names randomly (though that does happen).  But a more sophisticated and realistic fake profile could start with age and generate a selection of data most appropriate to that starting data.  I've averaged away the first name popularity that came in by decade, but that's what I mean.  Older people with common names of Michael, David, Lisa and Mary and younger ones with Jacob, Joshua, Emily and Madison.  That would be neat...  This is just a first stab in that direction.

 > @cbaines FYI, I'm looking at https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=816169 and it mentions the license as 'Expat', when in fact faker is released under MIT.

MIT is an ambiguous name that sometime refers to the Expat license (as it does in the case of fake-factory/faker), see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT_License#Various_versions for more information.

  Adds optional IPv4 and IPv6 network address generation with valid CIDR notation.

Also add corresponding unit-tests.

Usage example:

``` python
>>> from faker import Factory as FakerFactory
>>> faker = FakerFactory.create()
>>> faker.ipv4()
u'94.84.244.87'
>>> faker.ipv4(network=True)
u'105.0.0.0/10'
>>> faker.ipv4(network=True)
u'131.46.122.140/30'
>>> faker.ipv6()
u'0b9e:425c:8028:ffd1:88a1:9d54:a4a0:cafb'
>>> faker.ipv6(network=True)
u'1e1b:0791:da18:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000/45'
>>> faker.ipv6(network=True)
u'79c1:84fc:53b8:c9a8:23ca:7407:a775:0180/121'
```

 Hi @danhuss ,

I think this case is not generic enough to warrant being included in Faker. In other words, I don't think many people would find that useful.

You could still package your provider as a stand-alone Python package, and use it with faker.

Assuming your provider has an import path of `course_provider.Provider`:

```
from course_provider import Provider as CourseProvider
from faker import Faker

fake = Faker()
fake.add_provider(CourseProvider)

fake.grade()
```

  right now pip install  is broken due to the released package claiming to be universal wheel but not using environment markers

so pip makes a wheel for all pythons with the first python its run on, then its used on all other pythons,
so a pip install on python2.6 would create a broken wheel with the extra dependency which is then subsequently tried in other pythons, and will utterly break them
 yes
 the simple solution would be not claiming to be a universal wheel,
the more complete solution would be to set up environment markers for the affected python versions

  The provider data and provider logic are pretty tightly intertwined. 

It'd be nice if they were separated out--then it'd be a lot easier to port some of the other provider lists out there.

For example, look at how ForgeryPy structures the data separate from the logic--ForgeryPy dictionaries are the equivalent of Faker's Providers: https://github.com/tomekwojcik/ForgeryPy/tree/master/forgery_py/dictionaries

He's got a generic loader that kicks in when a custom function isn't defined for a provider. 

That project seems relatively abandoned, so it'd be nice to pull that clean functionality into this project. 

It'd also probably make it easier for people to localize their providers because they just change the data files without having to think about the attached python code. 
 This would probably help with #230, plus I suspect it'd also help with #86 because many of the contributions would be straight flat files rather than code + data. Unfortunately, it's also a lot of work, but I'd be willing to help and sounds like @kissarat would as well 
  The docs say:

  The `US_en` phone_number() provider [includes formats](https://github.com/joke2k/faker/blob/master/faker/providers/en_US/phone_number.py#-7-8) that can generate invalid phone numbers (i.e. numbers which can't be parsed as standard US numbers by  [phonenumbers.py](https://github.com/daviddrysdale/python-phonenumbers)):

```
import phonenumbers
from fake import Faker
faker = Faker()
number = faker.phone_number()
phonenumber.parse(number,'US')
```

The above code will return a `NumberParseException` if the phone number is generated using the first format, `'+##(#)##########'` with an invalid country code (e.g. `+08(1)111111111`). One possibility is to try and force this format to always use a valid country code following the `+`. However, because other providers/localizations can already be used to generate specific international number formats including leading country codes, etc... I think it'd be simpler to only include valid US numbers in the `US_en` provider. In this case, it'd be easiest to simply remove the `'+##(#)##########'` formats from the provider?

 Sure, no problem; here is the script (quick copy-and-paste):

```
# coding=utf-8

from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import requests


def replace_quotes(s):
    r = s
    for c in '"`':
        r = r.replace(c, "'")
    return r


def get_address_countries():
    lst = []
    url = 'http://nl.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ISO_3166-1&printable=yes'
    r = requests.get(url)
    soup = BeautifulSoup(r.text)
    # get the first table
    tbl = soup.body.find_all('table', class_="wikitable")[0]
    # process all rows
    for tr in tbl.find_all('tr'):
        # get the text of all columns
        rec = [td.get_text(strip=True) for td in tr.find_all('td')]
        if len(rec) > 0:
            # get the first column
            txt = replace_quotes(rec[0])
            lst.append(txt)
    return lst


def out_list(lst):
    lines = []
    line = 7*' '
    for e in lst:
        part = '"%s",' % (e,)
        if (len(line) + 1 + len(part)) >= 80:
            lines.append(line.rstrip())
            line = 8*' ' + part
        else:
            line += ' ' + part
    line = line.rstrip()
    if line:
        lines.append(line)
    return lines


def out_address_countries():
    lines = []
    line = 4*' ' + 'countries = ('
    lines.append(line)
    lst = get_address_countries()
    lines.extend(out_list(lst))
    line = 4*' ' + ')'
    lines.append(line)
    return lines


print "# faker/providers/nl_NL/address.py"
print
for line in out_address_countries():
    print line
```

The main magic is in the `out_list(lst)`, which is using double-quotes as there are single-quotes in the scraped data. It could be more generic, adding for example the number of spaces to indent and the actual quote style... but I'll leave that as an exercise for the reader ;-)

I've used the `out_list(lst)` method in another throw-away script, which just whacked the content out; feeding it the unmodified data from the localized providers that I was cleaning up. Then monkey at work to copy-and-paste the result back in. Note that after reading in the data, that typically would have a `lst.sort()` to ensure it complies with the coding guidelines.

  Fixes #118 by using a `fromtimestamp(0) + timedelta(seconds=ts)` approach, rather than a direct `fromtimestamp(ts)` (which fails on some platforms). This solves the `ValueError: timestamp out of range for platform time_t` as seen on some platforms (like my 32-bit Xubuntu 14.04 virtual machine using Python 2.7.6).

See http://stackoverflow.com/a/10588133/2315612 for details. I've included a note with this reference saying _'using datetime.fromtimestamp(ts) directly will raise a "ValueError: timestamp out of range for platform time_t" on some platforms due to system C functions'_ in-line. This is to help developers understand why this approach is needed and shouldn't be reverted.

from faker import Faker

Changing the above example to this:

``` python
 formats_male = {
        '{{first_name_male}} {{last_name}}’: 5,
        '{{prefix_male}} {{first_name_male}} {{last_name}}’: 1
        '{{first_name_male}} {{last_name}} {{suffix_male}}’: 1
        '{{prefix_male}} {{first_name_male}} {{last_name}} {{suffix_male}}’: 1
    }
```

to me, that looks quite a bit better and removes a lot of the duplicated code. I may not know immediately what the value does for the key, but it’s apparent that it does _something_, and the code itself is fairly easy to read. Other faker projects also seem to run into this trouble. Take this:

https://github.com/fzaninotto/Faker/blob/master/src/Faker/Provider/bg_BG/Internet.php

``` php
protected static $tld = array('bg', 'bg', 'bg', 'bg', 'bg', 'bg', 'com', 'biz', 'info', 'net', 'org’);
```

This could be simplified to (in Python) `tld = {‘bg’: 6, ‘com’:1, …}`
Which suggests that the problem isn’t limited to this project. Is it out of scope? That’s more of a philosophical problem, but I believe it’s a need that’s unfulfilled in the project. I can find an example of duplicated items in nearly every provider currently in the package.

If it’s clear that this is a good feature, then we can turn to implementation:

`random_element` right now works via `random.choice(list(obj))`. There’s no way that I know of to specify additional metadata on a list item to give it a weight. We could turn the list into a list of tuples with their weights attached, which is what I originally did by specifying [(object, weight_as_int), (object, weight_as_int)], but as you pointed out, the second element of a tuple for the weight isn’t a good idea. 

numpy attaches a list to the random_element call to give each element weight. That would work, but it’s decoupling the object from the weight unlike a dictionary. And if there are N elements in the list, for large Ns, updating the list would be difficult. But this project does not run into that issue of a huge list of formatters.

The simplest method is to use a dictionary where the object and the weight are closely coupled, and to update the base provider’s field to use the random_weighted_element function (or convert random_element to use the new method).

Moreover, we’d be adding in a dependency that doesn’t do anything different than what the PR already does with the standard library. The PR depends on random.choice(), and gives the user additional features.

The change itself doesn’t seem to affect timings either. With the changes merged:

```
In [16]: cProfile.run(‘fake.address()')

         298 function calls (249 primitive calls) in 0.000 seconds

```

and from the main branch:

```

In [5]: cProfile.run(‘fake.address()')

         283 function calls (234 primitive calls) in 0.000 seconds

```

In short - `random_weighted_element` is an unmet need, doesn’t impact other areas of functionality, and isn’t out of scope.

  The docs mention being able to call the seed() method so you can use a generated dataset as part of a unit test.

Due to the way Faker uses the random module, this usecase is a bit fragile.  Any modification to the data requested, or any outside uses of the random module during generation will diverge the dataset.

Here is a quick script demonstrating the problem along with a couple of potential solutions:

``` python
import random
from faker import Faker
fake = Faker()

# initial run
fake.seed(1234)
print fake.name()
print fake.name()
print fake.name()

# repeated run with same data
fake.seed(1234)
print fake.name()
print fake.name()
print fake.name()

# adding new fake calls prevent us from getting the same names we had originally
fake.seed(1234)
print fake.name(), fake.email()
print fake.name(), fake.email()
print fake.name(), fake.email()

# One way is to implement a preserve/restore mechanism so that the user can get back to the previous trail of data
fake.seed(1234)
print fake.name()
r = random.getstate()
print fake.email()
random.setstate(r)
print fake.name()
r = random.getstate()
print fake.email()
random.setstate(r)
print fake.name()
r = random.getstate()
print fake.email()
random.setstate(r)

# A similar problem arises if the program using faker happens to use a non-instance random call during generation.
# The best way to prevent this issue is to have faker use an instance of random rather than the module version.

# If faker used an instance version of random, you could also resolve the original problem by using different faker instances
fake.seed(1234)
fake2 = Faker()
fake2.seed(1234)
print fake.name(), fake2.email()
print fake.name(), fake2.email()
print fake.name(), fake2.email()
```
 I don't think that it will be that painful to try to clean up this issue.  I wish I wasn't so rusty with Python app development outside a small single script, or I'd try to put together a pull request for you, but I fear it wouldn't be adequate unless I put more time into it than I have available.

I definitely agree that Generator needs to get an instance of random rather than using the module static.  That is step 0.  Even just doing that one simple change would remove most of the problem and enable the approach I put at the bottom of my example where people could just spawn more than one faker object when they want to keep the seed stable.  I suggest testing against regression and then start by just releasing that.

If that goes well, the next thing I'd recommend would be adding two more methods to generator to allow checkpointing the random instance via getstate and setstate.  The end user wouldn't even have to store the state themselves, you would probably be fine introducing it as a type of transactional system where they could call a method like "savestate" before they start doing "weird" stuff, then call "restorestate" when they want to get back to normal.  save would call getstate and store the state in a instance variable, and restorestate would just call setstate to update the random instance back to where it was.

As for your worry about some methods using random a variable number of times, I'd be happy to look at it if you could point me at one, but I suspect they might not be a problem due to the pseudo nature of the prg.  Here is why I think that, let me know if I'm wrong.
Given three methods, a, b, and c.  Methods a and c each make a single call to random to do their work.  b will output an array of strings, between one and five.  The content of the strings is random, and the number of strings to be returned is also random.

Since all of the randomness in methods a, b, and c are based on the same rng, the random instance stored inside Generator, if a program calls a, then b, then c using the same initial seed, it should still get the same output.  The random number between 1 and 5 that b used to determine how many strings to output will always be the same given the same initial seed.
 Just to jump in with some initial assessment. @deinspanjer is correct. Checking the current state of the seed would be optimal. Based on my assessment, it seems that you have one single instance of the Generator object per factory. Thus, I have a possible simpler idea...
1. Make it so that seeding generates a new instance of the generator into a hashable table. 
   
   ###### Reasoning: Since python already states that the contents of calling `random.seed([x])` includes a value that must be hashable, including a hash array of generators would be ok. Due to `O(1)` complexity for accessing.
2. Focus should then be placed on how `random` is being used throughout the factory.
